sentence: US stocks were set to open with sizable gains Friday as China's efforts to prop up its economy followed early this morning by upbeat corporate earnings restored Wall Street's confidence and drove Dow futures more than 150 points higher.
Tech stocks are making an impressive comeback with chipmakers leading the advance, putting the Nasdaq on track to open over 30 points higher.

The overnight session was punctuated with a mostly negative data dump in China, another rout in Italian markets and news that President Trump and President Xi Jinping will likely meet at next month's G-20 conference, their first face-to-face in nearly a year.

Additionally, the diplomatic crisis between the US and Saudi Arabia lessened following reports that the kingdom has fingered a scape-goat for Jamal Khashoggi's death, and could replace divisive crown prince Mohammed bin Salman as heir with his younger and more predictable brother.
In the US, quarterly results from Honeywell ( HON ) and Dow component Proctor & Gamble ( PG ) catapulted stock futures higher.
Honeywell beat EPS estimates on revenue that was in-line with expectations.
Looking ahead, the company lowered its 2018 guidance to reflect the financial impact from its spinoffs.
Proctor & Gamble beat earnings forecasts by three cents on revenue that also exceeded expectations.

After Thursday's close, American Express ( AXP ) and PayPal ( PYPL ) both reported better-than-expected results and raised their full-year guidance driving share prices higher and giving a boost to the financial sector before the open.
In related markets, oil futures are gaining ground with Brent crude more than 1% higher; Treasury yields are higher as the 10-year note flirts with 3.20%; and gold is up for a second day.

Friday's calendar includes existing home sales at 10 am ET (est -0.7% to SAAR 5.30 million), the weekly oil rig count from Baker Hughes, and Fed presidents Raphael Bostic (Atlanta) and Rob Kaplan (Dallas) participating in economic events in their respective Fed districts this afternoon.

(-) EBAY (-5.77%) Downgraded at Stifel to hold from buy, PT lowered to $35 from $43
